turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll hear arguments next in Colby and Walters against Driver.
Mr. Nemser, you may proceed whenever you're ready.

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

Chief Justice Burger pointed out in this morning's arguments that the facts of this case aren't -- cases, the Colby case and the tandem case, the Stafford case this morning, are not the most important elements of the case because we're dealing with a relatively narrow personal jurisdiction issue.
But I thought I would just briefly give you the jurisdictional facts in the Colby case.
The jurisdictional facts are that Colby has no presence in Rhode Island and that Walters has no presence in Rhode Island.
Colby was Director of Central Intelligence.
His office was in Virginia.
He resides in Maryland.
General Walters was Deputy Director of Central Intelligence.
He resided in Virginia.
He now resides in Florida.

Judge Pettine found in the District Court in Rhode Island that Colby and Walters did not have sufficient presence in that district to satisfy the Rhode Island long-arm statute which is one of the broad ones that extends personal jurisdiction as far as Fourteenth Amendment due process will permit.
The facts of course in Colby involved the mail opening program and I think that's adequately been covered.

The -- there was one thing this morning that was discussed that I'd like to touch on before I talk about the two points I plan to talk about and that was Mr. Justice Stewart, you had a discussion with Mr. Brown and the question was, what about habeas corpus and what about Schlanger?
And wouldn't you have to or would you not have to reverse Schlanger if you didn't find for us in this case?
I think you'd have to reverse Schlanger.

The arguments for not reversing Schlanger would be that in habeas corpus there is a special jurisdictional section and the First Circuit held that habeas corpus falls into the otherwise provided by law Section 1391 (e).
Well, it does not.
I read 2241 at least a dozen times.
I just read it again and I read Strait against Laird.
24 -- 2241 does not provide for jurisdiction.
It does not provide for the venue.
All it says is that the courts can issue the writs within their respective jurisdictions.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well otherwise provided by law, it doesn't necessarily mean, otherwise provided by statutory law, does it?

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: I would presume that that's what Congress would have meant.
Now, Mr. --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I'm a -- and how about the last sentence in footnote 4 in the Schlanger opinion?
I read it this morning.
I don't have it in front of me.

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: Nevertheless, Schlanger says that habeas corpus isn't like in all respects every civil actions --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Or in civil actions or just generally?

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: And the point of that, Schlanger --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: He has special rules of law governing habeas corpus.

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: Wait a minute the -- the rule governing personal jurisdiction in habeas corpus is set forth in Strait against Laird where the court said and Mr. Douglas -- Justice Douglas wrote, that jurisdiction over the custodian is like any other rule of jurisdiction.
You've got to be present and he cites International Shoe.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.
But he also wrote Schlanger as we know.

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: He also wrote Schlanger and in Schlanger, what he said was -- the interesting thing about it was, in Schlanger he said the commanding officer and I quote, “But he was neither a resident of the Arizona judicial district nor amenable to its process.”
Now, if 1391 (e) makes federal officials amenable to process all throughout the country, you have to reverse Schlanger.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: As you know, I dissented in Schlanger, so that wouldn't (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: I know but I don't know why you dissented because you didn't file an opinion.
You didn't dissent straight though.
The -- the two points I want to make is what standard do you have to apply in evaluating this statute.

And I say that because of two sources, one, Justice Brandeis' opinion in Robertson and second, Mr. Chief Justice Burger's opinion in NLRB against Catholic Bishop of Chicago, the standard is, this statute cannot be interpreted to supply personal jurisdiction over federal officials throughout the United States unless there is clear expression of legislative intent.

That comes from Robertson, the standard from Catholic Bishop is -- because there's a substantial constitutional question presented, you can't read the statute to provide jurisdiction unless there's an affirmative intent of Congress clearly expressed.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what's a substantial constitutional question?
I mean it's a -- this is one country.

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: This is one country by the personal jurisdiction is no longer and it has never been held by this Court to be based solely on territorial power.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So, can the Securities Act provides for nationwide service of process?

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: Of course it does, but it's carefully limited.
It says, "You only have venue where the course of action arose, where the defendants reside, or where an act took place by a defendant."
So it certainly satisfies Fifth Amendment due process because there are some affiliating circumstances with the district.

And to go to the district, we commit securities fraud to defend an action doesn't seem to me to place an intolerable burden on the right to defend to coerce Colby to go to San Francisco, Rhode Island, New York, to defend the same action, to bring his witnesses, to go there for depositions.
I say, imposes intolerable burden on his right to defend his opportunity to be heard and in Boddie against Connecticut where to get a divorce you have to file a $12.00 filing fee.

This Court held at a minimum due process and this is in Fifth to Fourteenth Amendment had a minimum due process requires a meaningful opportunity to be heard and if you don't have the $14.00 for filing fee, you don't have that opportunity.Our clients cannot afford to run around the country defending actions because while they were federal officials, someone has a gripe.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But if Nelson Rockefeller when he were alive have been -- named a defendant presumably, he could be sued under your interpretation of the statute.
He couldn't certainly raise the “no means clause.”

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: I'm looking at the statute on its face.

And I say on its face to require someone, Nelson Rockefeller or anyone else to expand such a substantial amount of his assets to travel around the country defending lawsuits where they didn't ask for it.
They didn't step into a district would place an intolerable burden on that right to defend.
And the Court has never done otherwise.
Every time the Court's been faced with the issue of whether there's any Fifth Amendment limitation on Congress' power to provide nationwide jurisdiction they point it out in the case before them.
Well, here, there's no intolerable burden.
In our case, there is one.
And I pointed out in my supplemental brief that in Leroy case just recently decided.

In the dissenting opinion, I believe it was written by Mr. Justice White, he said, "Of course there's nationwide jurisdiction which is constitutional in the federal courts because there's no Fifth Amendment limitation."
But what does he cite?
No decision from this Court because there is none.
He decides -- he cites a Seventh Circuit case, the Simmons case which we discussed, he hasn't point out there's even a split in the Seventh Circuit.

In Metz Apparatewerke cited in my brief, the Seventh Circuit said, "Yes, there is a finest limitation on the exercise of power to -- congressional power to provide nationwide jurisdiction and it's fundamental fairness, fair play similar to the International Shoe standard."
The -- the thing that I believe, it would be unconstitutional if you applied it in our case but I believe that there is no question that there's a substantial question raised.
Henry-Hatton and Hatton-Wexler discussed it and say, it's a substantial question, the Fifth Amendment and the Fourteenth Amendment have the same language, due process.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What is the venue situation before 1962 when someone who felt he'd been wrong by Government action and wanted to sue a Government official clearly had to come back to the District of Columbia or Maryland or Virginia where that citizen resided and sued them?
He couldn't sue them anywhere else in United States.

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: That's right, because only Maryland or D.C. could issue mandamus.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, doesn't that suggest the same fairness problem?
Here, someone maybe wronged 3000 miles away?

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: Unfair to the plaintiff you mean?
Well, due process protects defendants.
You shouldn't have your property taken away without due process of law.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, it may will.

The complaint of this person may well have been that the Government agent living in Maryland or Virginia or the District of Columbia took away his property without due process of law out on the State of Washington.

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: And it would be fundamentally unfair to make him travel to Washington to prosecute his case as a plaintiff.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: It seems to me that would be as reasonable an argument as the one you are making now.

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: I -- I think it -- I was -- I would be sympathetic to his plight and Congress was, but the question of what due process prevents in a litigation protects in a litigation setting, it protects defendants, and it's been pointed out by this Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, but due process is applicable only when we're talking about the jurisdiction of a court and this -- we're dealing here with the venue of the statute.

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: Well, the question in this case also is whether this statute provides personal jurisdiction.
We have a section on our main brief which is devoted to that and we say, it supplies only venue not personal jurisdiction.
The -- the question of whether it provide -- if it didn't provide personal jurisdiction, we would be out of the case because there'd be no basis to have personal jurisdiction over us.
Our argument was discussed in the First Circuit's opinion and rejected.
I believe it is a valid argument.
I believe it is valid because Congress often times provides for service of process.
The federal rules tell you how to serve process but they don't tell you when someone is amendable to service or subject to jurisdiction.
That whole area is based on another area of the law, presence, specific jurisdictional statute and the Robertson case is instructive there.
The Court should not interpret a statute to provide in personam jurisdiction because we have general rules about it unless --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But -- but as you suggested in your answer to my Brother Rehnquist about the security's legislation, venue under those laws must be in several alternative places.

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But jurisdiction is nationwide, isn't it?

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: Service of process is nationwide.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And as to personal jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's what -- that's (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: The service of process isn't the same as personal jurisdiction.
For example, in New York, the long-arm statute --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The jurisdiction is not the same as venue, that's what -- that was my --

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- the point of my question.

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: There are three things we're talking about, service, venue, and personal jurisdiction.
The -- the general rule of personal jurisdiction set forth in the Robertson case is that you get sued, defendants get sued to where they live, where they're present, where they're found.

Robertson said, there have been very few departures from this general rule and they've all been carefully guarded and clearly expressed and it shouldn't be likely assumed that Congress intends and to depart from long established policies.
So, what do we have to get congressional intent?
Ms. Peterson this morning said, we have a lot of discussion about damage actions, we did not.
As Justice Stevens pointed out, there's this passing reference in the hearings where four congressmen where present, just four.
Where MacGuineas and if you read the hearings, you could tell this subcommittee did not like MacGuineas.
He was bothering them.
He told them, you're giving us problems that -- the committee said to MacGuineas, you're giving us problems that we don't want to deal with.
You're telling us that we're going to go to official's pocketbooks.
We're not dealing with that.
We don't want to deal that.
By the way, you're too busy to study this, you tell us, they say in the hearings, "You're too busy trying cases, bring someone else down from justice to talk to us."
They were tired of hearing from him.
So what did they do?
They put in their committee report the thing that was before all the congressmen what was intended by the statute, what's it say?
It's -- it's got one theme.
These are Government suits, suits against the Government.
It says, it covers suits against Government officials that can now be brought only in D.C. not my case, not the personal damage cases, suits to compel a federal officer to perform a duty.
Three times it says, suits in essence against the United States.
Twice it says, we're talking about suits nominally against officials.

It goes on to say, we're talking about suits against officials as individuals but when we sue them under the fiction that they're acting us individuals and it says, there's no problem in this case, it tells Congress this committee report.
There's no problem because the Government always defends them.
Now, it's incredible to me that it can be suggested that Congress was alerted in the face of all this.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right on that very point about Government, all its defense.
What -- what would you say today as to the application of a statute to a liable action such as Barr against Matteo or one of those.

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: 1391 (e) doesn't apply because they're trying to get money out of his pocketbook.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Is the -- I take it the government probably would defend (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: The Government would defend only if it found, A, it was in the interest the United States to defend them, B, to defend and acted within the scope with his authority, and C, the defendant didn't commit any crime and there's no criminal investigation.
Now, in a related case, the Blackburn case which Mr. Brown mentioned this morning, (Inaudible) the defendant but he was criminally investigated, so he pays his own attorney's fees.
If the Government decides it's no longer in their interest to defend my client, my client will have to pay.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But the letter from Attorney General Katzenbach to the District Attorneys sort of assumes that they will be defending this slander libel type suits against the officer, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: The Katzenbach memorandum -- Katzenbach is not a Congressman, he was not a Congressman.s

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I know -- I understand -- all that -- I'm not -- I'm just going to the one point that letter (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: If he assumes --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: -- assuming, those would be in the category that the Government would normally defend.

turn.speaker: earl_h_nemser
turn.label: Mr. Earl H. Nemser
turn.text: That memorandum assumed it and he did not talk about the three exceptions which are in 28 CFR 50.15.
It's not regulations.
It's just Justice Department policy which can change tomorrow or the next day.
We submit our case.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Ms. Stillman.

turn.speaker: elinor_h_stillman
turn.label: Ms. Elinor Hadley Stillman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
It is beyond dispute that the Venue Expansion Bill, the Representative Hamer Budge first introduced in the 86th Congress would not had if enacted have covered suits like the ones here today.

Yet, applied only to suits against federal officers in their official capacity and at the opening of the hearings on that bill in the 86th Congress, Representative Budge described the kinds of suits and the kind of venue problem he was concerned with in terms that clearly exclude the kinds of suits we have here today.

Respondents contend and the court below found that by adding the phrase “under color of legal authority,” the committee considering Representative Budge's bill, thereby extended the venue provision to include these types of tort damage suits.

We believe that in examination of the circumstances under which this phrase got add into the legislation and emerged in the Revised Bill H.R. 12622, that's the subject of the -- of the report issued in the 86th Congress reveals that they're wrong.

And we submit that the conclusion deserved from this -- derive from this examination of circumstances is confirmed by the explanation of the phrase in -- which is supplied in both House Reports, the one issued in the 86th Congress and the one issued in the 87th Congress.

And by remarks of Representative Poff, who is a member of the subcommittee that considered that bill in the 86th Congress and who made remarks in the 87th Congress when the bill was initially passed by the House containing this phrase “under color of legal authority.”

And I'm going to devote most of point time here to discussing how this phrase got into the bill and how it's explained in the House Reports and what Congressman Poff said this bill was all about when he explained it to his fellow Congressmen.

As I said, it's important to focus on the -- on the original bill in the 89th Congress because that's where the phrase came in and that's where some of these troubles since then have first appeared in that report.

Regarding that original bill, it's true as Mrs. Peterson has said here this morning that Deputy Attorney General Walsh had written a letter to the Congress about that original bill that mentioned only official capacity.
And he pointed out that it appeared to cover only mandamus actions the bill therefore knew nothing, because no court outside of the District of Columbia Circuit had mandamus jurisdiction.

He also did mention that there were two categories of cases involving suits against defendants and their individual capacity as federal officers and their individual capacity which would not be covered by the bill as drafted.

One category of suits was the suits against the individual where you were -- you had a legal fiction that the man was acting outside of his authority in order to evade the sovereign immunity doctrine.

The other category of suits was -- were suits to seek damage from him personally for actions taken ostensibly on the course of his official duties but which the plaintiff claims were in -- excessive of official authority.
In the hearings on Representative Budge's bill, MacGuineas reiterated these points and he again pointed out that one category of these suits involved this legal fiction.

In view of Representative Budge's opening statement of what he intended the bill to cover, it was quite obvious that this first category of suits, the legal fiction category had to be covered in order for Representative Budge's bill to do what he wanted to do.

And that was to give review of administrative action out in the field against field officers without having your action foreclosed because the indispensable superior, party superior was in Washington.
Therefore, if they didn't put something in the bill, the whole purpose of the bill was going to be undermined.
The phrase “under color of legal authority” was suggested by Committee Counsel Melvin Drabkin.
And it's true that he had times in the hearing seem to distinguish suits -- personal suits for personal actions, personal -- outside the scope of employment actions against federal defendants.
But he also said at page 57 of the hearings to MacGuineas, "I don't want the Government to be able to retreat behind any artificial concepts."
So, what he seem to fear was that something was going on here, if they didn't change it in some way, the Government was going to somehow escape review.
And it is true that MacGuineas pointed out that if you added this phrase “under color of legal authority,” there was the danger.
The possibility that some court might construe it to cover tort damage suits against the officials.

And then he said quite forcefully that this would be grossly unfair to federal officials because certainly, private individuals are not subject to suits in multiple forums for torts committed in the course of their employment and it was unfair to -- to treat federal officials differently for damage suits.
And slander actions were discussed as -- as a sort of paradigm case of these types that -- of suits that might possibly be covered.
However, as soon as he had finished discussing this -- this possibility, the Committee Chairman and another committee member immediately agreed that it would be unfair.
This was Representative Forrester and Representative Poff and that's at page 63 of the transcript of hearings.
But the Congressman had several reasons to discount MacGuineas' fears that the courts would construe the language to reach this result that they agreed with was -- was unfair.

First, Judge Albert Maris who -- representing the judicial conference testified really something of an expert witness, they seem to treat him as someone who knew how courts might interpret things and who knew what language should be used to -- to achieve their purposes, and he was asked, "Would it be advisable to add this phrase under color of legal authority?"
And he said, "I would be very happy to see that, because it would be a way of putting to rest this fictional doctrine and get right down of what is really the fact reviewing administrative action."
That's at page 91 of the transcript of hearings.

Second, they had reason to discount this possibility that MacGuineas was holding up to them because the sponsor of the bill, Hamer Budge, disavowed on the record any intent of covering what he called, the slander type actions.
He said, "This is not what I have in mind."
And as Justice Steven has pointed out, that was mainly what they focused on when they were giving examples of what damage actions might possibly be involved.

Third, the House Report issued shortly after these hearings concluded explained the reason for referring both the suits against officers acting in their official capacity and the suits against offers -- officers acting under color of legal authority and that explanation which is printed at page 37 of our brief and in language that has been quoted this morning by Mr. Nemser is written in terms that clearly not referred to these types of suits but clearly refer to suits in essence against the Government suits, in essence against the United States suits that involve this legal fiction.
Now, we submit that -- that these factors, these circumstances would have made the Congressman feel that perhaps MacGuineas was being unnecessarily finicky, unnecessarily fearful.
Clearly they thought he was there trying to throw up problems to dissuade them from legislating anything at least they seem to express that feeling at times.

And both the Senate and the House Reports on H.R. 1960 in the 87th Congress, started out describing the purpose of the bill, the bill -- the bill as a whole, not just the mandamus section, but the bill as a whole is being something that they're passing to facilitate review of administrative action.
And we submit that damage suits are not what you're talking about when you talk about review of administrative action.
Congressman Poff, made remarks in connection with this bill when it was voted on by the House in the 87th Congress.

Now, this is -- when it was first voted on by the House, there were subsequently some amendments which don't directly affect us here and it was then revoted on by the House but -- but he was explaining to the Congress that was going to pass on this bill what it meant.
And at this time, it did contain a phrase under legal -- “under color of legal authority.”
Representative Poff's remarks which are printed at Volume 107 of the congressional record, page 12157, "Are cast in terms that refer only to suits that are in essence against the government itself."

He speaks of the balance of convenience between plaintiff and defendant in such suits, and insists that broadening the plaintiffs' options presents no problem, because as he observes, there are federal courts, federal attorneys, federal marshals, and federal agencies in every quarter of the nation, and that in fact the convenience of the Government would be promoted by trying the case in the local District Court where the paper is available, the property is accessible, and the witnesses are within easy reach.
Representative Poff ended his remarks with the following statement, "Our Nation was founded upon a profound respect for the rights of the individual citizen.
The Government should be willing always to accommodate itself to the preservation of these rights more particularly, when the Government is the party in controversy with the private citizen."

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And by the government you read that as meaning the particular governmental official who had --

turn.speaker: elinor_h_stillman
turn.label: Ms. Elinor Hadley Stillman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- done something that was thought he should not have done, or she --

turn.speaker: elinor_h_stillman
turn.label: Ms. Elinor Hadley Stillman
turn.text: Yes, right.
And what you're reviewing is government action.
We're not seeking to have some kind of damage and compensation for some injury that was done to you in the past.
You're reviewing the action, and generally, you're asking for injunctive relief.
Make him stop -- do it, don't let him do it again, and getting some ruling on whether it's a legal action or not.
The damage suits here today are not controversies between the Government and respondents in these cases.
They are suits for damages to be paid out of assets of the individual petitioners.
In this case, Mr. Colby and Mr. Walters, who as pointed out, are now private citizens.
It is true that they have been supplied with government-paid private counsel, but as noted, that is not assured in all cases.

There are these factors that have to be satisfied, that there's a determination that they were acting in the scope of their employment, that there's a determination that it's in the interests of the United States to provide representation to them.

And as far as the private counsel program, private counsel are paid for when there's some possibility of conflict in representing all of the defendants, or some other problem with arguments that might wish to be raised, or any other factors.
This is not assured at all, because this is subject to annual budgetary appropriations which may or may not come about from year to year.
So there simply cannot be any assurance that Government representation is always there.
In fact, I think at one point in the transcript, there was some reference to suits against Congressmen, and one of the Representatives said to MacGuineas, don't you always defend these?
And he said, “Well, sometimes we do and sometimes we don't.”
So it wasn't assured.
It is easy to see in retrospect that greater care might have been taken by Congress to assure that Courts would not construe 1391 (e) more broadly than Congress evidently intended.

But we submit that the language that Congress did employ, "under color of legal authority" is not in itself so clearly indicative of an attempt to change this historic, defendant-oriented venue rules, that you simply ignore all of these other considerations that I've discussed here.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mrs. Stillman, has ever -- has anyone to your knowledge ever considered the possibility that the language might be descriptive of the character of the defendant while he's defending the lawsuit?

turn.speaker: elinor_h_stillman
turn.label: Ms. Elinor Hadley Stillman
turn.text: You mean at the time?
In other words, refers to his capacity --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: In which each defendant is an officer.
Now that's no longer true of these people.
Or an employee acting either in his official capacity or still acting under color of legal authority in trying to defend the Government's actions.

turn.speaker: elinor_h_stillman
turn.label: Ms. Elinor Hadley Stillman
turn.text: That certainly, Your Honor, I think is suggestive of an intent to --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: If you read it that way, of course, you --

turn.speaker: elinor_h_stillman
turn.label: Ms. Elinor Hadley Stillman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: But did anybody ever suggest it should be read that way, to your knowledge?

turn.speaker: elinor_h_stillman
turn.label: Ms. Elinor Hadley Stillman
turn.text: Well, I think that the petitioners may have suggested that to the First Circuit.
But as I understand Your Honor, that if it's read that way it's clearly suggestive of having some kind of active supervision over their -- what they're doing, and it's --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well, there's (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: elinor_h_stillman
turn.label: Ms. Elinor Hadley Stillman
turn.text: -- suggestive of injunctive relief, certainly.
And I think that's a plausible reading of the statute.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Nobody really argues it here.
I just -- was trying to --

turn.speaker: elinor_h_stillman
turn.label: Ms. Elinor Hadley Stillman
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: -- maybe it's so fanned so far out --

turn.speaker: elinor_h_stillman
turn.label: Ms. Elinor Hadley Stillman
turn.text: I -- I would --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: -- that it doesn't make any sense but I just wasn't sure.

turn.speaker: elinor_h_stillman
turn.label: Ms. Elinor Hadley Stillman
turn.text: I would never want to resist an argument that would tend to support the position that we're supporting.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's -- that's dealt with in note 8 of -- in the opinion of the Court of Appeals on page 5 of the appendix to the petition to --

turn.speaker: elinor_h_stillman
turn.label: Ms. Elinor Hadley Stillman
turn.text: Alright, and I'm advised that it's in petitioner's brief at page 5.
In -- in summary, I would just simply like to note that we think that the circumstances that I've noted here really compellingly suggest what the congressional purpose was in this statute.

And that any memorandum that Attorney General Katzenbach may have written three months later or -- and certainly the letter of Deputy Attorney General White which can be read as merely to say, there might be a problem, the courts might construe this way, you might consider making it more clearly are not enough to compel the really radical change in venue rules which the construction given to the statute by the respondents and by the court below would effect.
Thank you Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Wulf?

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
I am not even going to try to improve upon the very specific description of the legislative history that Ms. Peterson presented to the Court this morning.
I couldn't improve on it if I did try.
I did think it was very precise and persuasive, and presented our perspective in distinction to the opposing side's perspective very well.

What I would like to do is put some -- put this case into a concrete context, and discuss some of the pragmatic and policy consideration which I think may properly inform the Court's ultimate decision in the case.
And for that purpose, with your leave, Mr. Chief Justice, I would like to allude briefly to the facts of the Colby case, because I think they dramatize what is at stake here.
This case arose out of the 20-year program of the CIA to open first class mail going to and from the United States and the Soviet Union.
It was conducted without consent of any of the correspondents.
It was conducted without a warrant ever being issued or applied for.
It was, I think it cannot be plainer, illegal and in violation of the Fourth Amendment to the United States.
In the course of the program, the CIA opened about 215,000 letters affecting 110,000 individuals, American citizens.

In response to that, when the program became known in 1975, this suit was filed in order to vindicate the rights of the persons whose mail was opened and whose constitutional rights have been so sorely abused by their government, and by the officials who represented the government.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Wulf, we said before maybe the merits really aren't too relevant.
But what is the case that holds that there's a plain violation of Fourth Amendment rights here?

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: There are two cases.

From Ex Parte Jackson in 1880, I believe, to United States versus Van Leeuwen which was about 10 years ago, both in this case -- both in this Court, Your Honor, where it was held that a warrant was required in order to justify opening of first class mail matter.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: With a foreign -- first class foreign mail?

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: It -- they were both domestic cases, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: We had case involving foreign mail recently that --

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: -- doesn't really support you very much.
I dissented from the case.
Well -- I guess it isn't relevant, but sometimes --

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: Well, but there may have been probable -- I recollect the case to which you refer, and that was an obscenity case, I believe, was it not?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We -- we had them -- that mail cover case two or three years ago from the Court of Appeals, the District of Columbia Circuit.

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: Sorry.
I -- I don't recollect.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That was opening mail at the border.

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: Yes.

In any case, I think that there would be a very, very strong, indeed, irresistible argument that this program, which in fact included outgoing mail, not only incoming mail, which I think would change it substantially, was a plain violation of the Fourth Amendment.
The question --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, are you -- are you suggesting, Mr. Wulf, that there would be no violation opening at the border?

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: No, I think it was a violation both ways, Your Honor, yes, incoming and outgoing.

The question -- the question then becomes whether the citizens whose rights were injured in this case can have a convenient mode of redress for the serious -- for the serious intrusion upon their constitutional rights.

And the Senate Report concerning this statute before us today in fact says that its purpose, in addition to everything else it says, which is in dispute before the Court, this is not in dispute, it says that the purpose of 1391 (e) is to provide readily available, inexpensive judicial remedies for the citizen who was aggrieved by the workings of Government.
In this particular case, the plaintiffs had two options, apart from the one which we are arguing in support of today.

If he cannot bring the action in the district where he lives, where Mr. Driver lives, he would either have to go to the several districts where the individual defendants reside, or he would have to go to the jurisdiction where the cause of action arose.

As an individual citizen it would be equally burdensome for him to have to travel to New York, where it would appear that the cause of action arose, and even more burdensome to have travel around the country to find -- to file individual suits against the several defendants in this case.

The convenient thing, that condition which would satisfy the stated objective of the Senate in this -- in adopting this statute, allows them to file suit conveniently and inexpensively in the jurisdiction where he resides.
So that he may easily vindicate the violation of his constitutional and statutory rights.
And that convenience, of course, is one that was explicitly in the minds of Congress when they passed this statute.
And that is -- those are the interests represented on the plaintiffs' side of this case.
Congress has declared that where Government officials violate citizens' rights, that the plaintiffs should be easily able to get judicial vindication.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, now, that's a shorthand summary, I take it, of the first pair -- the first line of the venue section we're talking about.

Do you -- do you think if, in the Stafford case, that if Judge Stafford had not been sued until he had become a judge, but the suit was based on his activities as a United States attorney, he would have been subject to a venue under that section?

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: I -- I think so, Your Honor.

Because it was -- it was our position in the First Circuit that this statute applied so long as the defendant was a serving government official at the time service was made upon them, and that a change in status thereafter was -- did not affect the effective jurisdiction that was secured in the first place.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Even though it might be a quite different position that he occupied at the time of service then the relief was sought for his acts -- on the merits?

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: Our position in the First Circuit was that the different position made no difference at all, that it was the question -- the only -- the determinative question was whether the defendant was a serving government officer at the time process was served -- effectively served upon him.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, in the District Court, I thought that you successfully made the claim that the test was whether or not he was a government officer at the time that the cause of action arose.

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: You're quite right.
I'm afraid I put that part of the case somewhat out of my mind since it's not here.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And then that was -- that part was rejected by the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And we did not grant certiorari on that question, is that correct?

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: That's correct, yes.
Yes, thank you for clarifying that.
It was in fact our position that it apply to present and former officials.
It's our -- it's now our position that it applies under any circumstances as long as process was served at -- when the defendant was a serving government official, yes.

To be balanced against the considerations in the plaintiff's favor in these cases, in order to provide a simple, convenient, and inexpensive means of redress for injured citizens, are the interests of the defendants in this case.

And whether you consider this part of my argument as being in response to Mr. Nemser's constitutional argument, or merely as a -- as helping to inform the Court's decision in the statutory interpretation process, it really comes down to the same thing.
Because what I'm -- because the balance of interests asserted by the defendants in this case are not real.
And they would affect both the -- they would affect the due process argument if the Court thinks seriously that there is a due process argument.

But in any case, those interests, as I say, are not real, and are pallid in contrast to the real, palpable interests that are advanced on plaintiffs' behalf in a situation such as this, where a violation of constitutional rights is concerned.
In the first place, and I think critically, the petitioners and the Government would have you think these are just any old defendants.
These are not any old defendants.
These are government officials.
These are men and women who took an oath when they took office to uphold and defend the Constitution of the United States, and not to violate the laws and Constitution of the United States.
The Constitution doesn't apply to private citizens, it only applies to government --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Since when?
Since when was that true?

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: I'm sorry?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The Constitution applies to everybody in the United States of America.

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: It's enforceable but it's enforceable only against government officials, of course.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, not the Fifteenth Amendment, for example.

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: The Bill of Rights, Your Honor; sorry.
The -- the provision -- the provisions of the Bill of Rights which are before the Court today, the Fourth Amendment and the Fifth and Sixth Amendments.

And in that sense these defendants are in fact different because they assume the responsibility that private citizens do not have, and having assumed that responsibility they should be, and can be, in a constitutional and non-constitutional sense, be dealt with differently because they are different.
That seems to me to be a fundamental conception which the petitioners would have you overlook.

In addition to that, in this, in both of these cases, and for the foreseeable future until the Code of Federal Regulations is amended, there is the additional fact that there is no burden today on these defendants, because of the fact that the Government is paying what is the principal burden apart from a judgment, in defense of a lawsuit, and that is the fees of attorneys to represent a person who is sued.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But the -- any given Attorney General can terminate that arrangement any time he wants, can't he?

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: Could, but we're -- but this case should be judged by the events and by the situation as it now exists.
The provision for --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: So far as we know, the Attorney General might do nothing for them after any given day.
There have been times when the Attorney General has refused to represent in a setting like this.

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: There -- there have been, I -- they have been -- they have been rare, as far as I know.
It seems to me --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: There are going to be attorney's fees, even if the petitioners prevail here, I take it.
The -- your people will find them in whatever district they are and they'll have to hire attorneys to fight the lawsuit.
I had understood their argument to be principally the kind of a ping pong effect of having to answer depositions and that sort of thing in a place far from where they resided.

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: That's a -- that's a prospect, of course.

As a matter of fact, this suit has been in litigation for -- it was filed in -- summer of 1975, and there have been a lot of court appearances in the District Court and Court of Appeals, and I have yet to see a defendant, literally.
So it's been no burden yet.
If we get pass this argument, and if we prevail, then all of the instances that attend to the litigation process are going to come into being.
But even though they may have to travel, I mean, in balancing the equities, they may have to travel, they may have to travel to my office if I note the depositions to be taken there.
But the fact is that that might occupy a day of their time, maybe two days, depending on who the individual defendant is.

But we all know that it's the cost of attorney's fees that is the great burden in the defense of litigation, and that the time -- although if it were going to be a protracted trial elsewhere, that might also occupy some of their time.
But that's not a serious burden, it seems to me.
It's not a serious burden to cast upon individuals who are charged, as they are here, with violating the constitution.

And it's all a balancing process, as we know, and that to simplify and make convenient the right of citizens to vindicate their constitutional rights, and to weigh that against such relatively insignificant considerations, I think such as a little time -- the defendants --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, I -- I still don't understand your attorney's fees argument, because it seems to me that if you lose here, and the statute is construed the way the Second Circuit construed it, it doesn't mean you can't sue these people.
It means that you simply have to sue them somewhere else.
And if -- when you sue them somewhere else, they're going to have to retain attorneys where you sue them.

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: Well, that's true.
The balance of advantage then shifts, Your Honor, because then there'll be a much-increased burden upon the plaintiffs.
And although it might not make any difference in this case, since the plaintiffs in fact are being represented at no cost by the ACLU, this really isn't the paradigmatic case.
I would ask you to think of a case where -- which is a little case, where the ACLU was not representing the plaintiffs, where it's an individual who --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I thought you always represented little people? [Laughter]

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: Well, in this case, we represent little people, but in large volume. [Laughter]

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What is new, Mr. Wulf, about the idea that plaintiffs in lawsuits have greater burdens than the defendants at the onset?
They have the burden of proof, they have the burden of beginning the litigation.
That's -- that's always been true, hasn't it?

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: I frankly think, Mr. Chief Justice, that this case presents the Court with the question whether in suits by citizens to vindicate violations of constitutional rights, it doesn't want to shift the burden.

And that in the interests of defending the constitution, and in the interests of allowing successful vindication, convenient vindication and inexpensive vindication of the violation of constitutional rights, that the Court oughtn't construe this statute to serve that purpose.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But under your reading of the venue statute, it wouldn't have to be a constitutional violation

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: -- No.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: -- that you could bring the man 2000 miles for.
It could be a statutory violation.

turn.speaker: melvin_l_wulf
turn.label: Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
turn.text: Yes, well I think it comes to the same thing.
A violation is -- may be more profound if it's a constitutional violation, but still, a statutory violation is serious enough by itself.
It doesn't -- I'm not making any distinction between the two -- the two sorts.
Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I think the time is all consumed.
Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
Thank you Mrs. Stillman.
We'll hear arguments next in the United States against --
